data.title: Rap â€“ good singing gum
data.meta_description: Posts about Rap written by goodsinginggum
data.text:
Iâ€™m not sure if Dom Kennedy would appeal to a hip-hop outsider: his flows are a little off-kilter; his rhymes often slow. But a couple of key early 2010s hip-hop moments helped me really appreciate this dude. The first is â€œReal Estatesâ€ from Curren$yâ€™s Pilot Talk 2 (2010), an album that is (along with the preceding Pilot Talk) a benchmark for the kind of stoner rap music that doesnâ€™t really exist anymore. â€œThe game donâ€™t get any realerâ€ chirped Dom on his knot-tight â€œReal Estatesâ€ verse. Then 2012â€™s â€œGroovelineâ€ (Schoolboy Q , 2012) verse showcased his relaxed playboy style, ending hilariously with a â€œDom Kennedyâ€ drop that sounds like a producer tag.

I never followed him enough to track a new release, but when Frank Ocean included â€œT P Oâ€ on his blonded radio it seemed like a good idea to check out this album. â€œT P Oâ€ is a mellow slap, immediately memorable for the beatâ€™s harpsichord melody, but itâ€™s also funny: â€œI was young, but I went to the Grand Canyon once / Now Iâ€™m at a stripper house makinâ€™ tacos, rollinâ€™ blunts.â€ The song exemplifies this album as a whole, which is Dom Kennedy at his best: a realist who is cool, confident and relatable, with fantastic production choices. Clearly following the mold of 90s LA g-funk, â€œDominic, Pt. 2â€ updates the style with fantastic synth notes.

In college I fantasized about living in California and listening to â€œCaliforniaâ€, and now I can finally do it. Something about the drums on this oneâ€¦ I would play this over and over again on my little wired earbuds walking around in the cold Pennsylvania winter daydreaming about life in Cali. â€œWake up at 1:30, In-N-Out â€˜fore it close / Catch me in the drive-thru, then spin out on these hoes.â€ Sounds like a good time, manâ€¦ my plays of â€œCaliforniaâ€ dwarf the rest of the album.

I think sometimes Dom Kennedy is unintentionally funny or irreverent. Like, â€œSince Weâ€™re Telling the Truthâ€ is ostensibly a love song, but the chorus ends with â€œI could have a statue downtown.â€ The lyrics â€œEven if I was starvinâ€™ / Iâ€™m the type to pass on baloney / Walkman by Sony / Iâ€™m big as Tony, Toni, Tone,â€ read like Riff Raff bars, but theyâ€™re delivered earnestly over the heavenly beat of â€œWhen Iâ€™m Missinâ€™ Uâ€. Maybe itâ€™s just the nostalgia, but I see these as pluses.

This album was not received well. You have to really dig Dom as a kind of normal-guy-who-likes-hanging-out if you want to sit through this whole record, which could be 3-4 tracks shorter. But revisiting it today it still strikes me as underrated.

Listen to Los Angeles Is Not For Sale, Vol.1 here.

I first discovered this one in 2016, and revisiting it recently I thought, â€œthis is definitely the best thing Kool Keithâ€™s ever doneâ€. But then I was like, wait, Sex Style is really goodâ€¦ actually, The Cenubites is really goodâ€¦ actually, Critical Beatdown is REALLY good. And thatâ€™s not to mention any of the 25(!) or so albums Keith has released so far this millennium, most of which I havenâ€™t heard. So you canâ€™t really jump to a clear best with this guy.

Keith was and always has been a trailblazer, and this is clear from the title and cover here alone. The damn Elvis wigâ€¦ and with the flashy, turn-of-the-millennium neon green style this looks more like an N*Sync album cover than a rap record. But what lies within is hardly pop or R&B. Itâ€™s Keithâ€™s signature bizzaro-rap, a two-sided journey through the mind of a hip-hop visionary.

Whereas Dan the Automator produced the bulk of Keithâ€™s most popular Dr. Octagonecologyst (1996), Keith handles the production here himself (with frequent collaborator Kutmasta Kurt assisting). The result is a consistent and original sound, with enough synths and beeps to fit the space theme, but enough bass and kick to feel like pure hip-hop.

Keithâ€™s rap style is wild because he has an effortless cool (he was well over a decade deep in the rap game by the time of this recording) but heâ€™s also a weird motherfucker. â€œKeep it simple, baby young girl / Now squeeze your pimple,â€ he raps on â€œStaticâ€. This Sadat X feature is great because Sadat is another OG who also has an idiosyncratic and funny style, like when he starts singing â€œour house in the middle of our streetâ€ in the middle of his verse. â€œThe year 2005â€¦â€ Keith begins on â€œLost in Spaceâ€, which is more â€œStar Trekkin'â€ than any other rap song I can think of. These are just a couple of highlights early on.

As good as the Lost in Space side is here, I think I would give the win to Black Elvis, the second half of this record. Kid Capri sets it off, and then â€œBlack Elvisâ€ and â€œMaxi Curlsâ€ have some of the fastest rapping on the album, Keith dropping his Supreme Clientele-like stream-of-consciousness raps (except this album came first). â€œThe Girls Donâ€™t Like the Jobâ€ is one of the best examples of Keithâ€™s uniqueness: his weird falsetto chorus and strange subject matter â€“ â€œWith a loan from General Mills I would start a new NBA team in Baldwin Hills: / The Baldwin Hills Spacemen / Lime green uniformsâ€¦ I ripped up four tickets to the Grammy Awardsâ€. â€œCliftonâ€ features Keithâ€™s perfect foil Motion Man, probably the only guy on his level of bizarre. No strangers to alter egos, they appear here as â€œClifton Santiagoâ€ and â€œKeith Televasquezâ€, a duo of sex-crazed bandits. Things get rounded out with â€œAll the Timeâ€ (one of the more straightforward tracks here) and â€œI Donâ€™t Playâ€, which was lyrically interpolated by Deftones on â€œBack to Schoolâ€, the first track on White Pony â€“ this should probably tell you something about the reach of Kool Keithâ€™s influence.

Three months ago, Keith released Black Elvis 2, a sequel 24 years in the making. I havenâ€™t heard it, but heâ€™s on tour now. By the time he plays San Francisco in October, heâ€™ll be 60. For this yearâ€™s â€œHip-Hop Turns 50â€ reflections, Kool Keith described himself as â€œa one-person Parliament-Funkadelicâ€ to The New York Times. And like George Clinton, itâ€™s amazing to look back at his wide body of work and marvel at the fact that heâ€™s still doing it.

Listen to Black Elvis / Lost in Space here.

Wait, that album coverâ€™s not crazy enoughâ€¦ hold onâ€¦

There we go.

Deeper than Encyclopedia Brittanicaâ€¦

In 2006, XXL ran an online piece on the 90s label Suave House. Black Ice, the writer of the article, states that â€œstarting completely independent in 1993 and then getting national distribution through Relativity Records and eventually Universal, Suave opened the floodgates in the mid-90s for Southern imprints to secure support from major labels,â€ and that the artists on the label lived in an actual house together.

Presumably this group included 8Ball & MJG, Memphis hip-hop legends who released their first four albums on Suave House, years before becoming immortalized on Three 6 Mafiaâ€™s â€œStay Flyâ€. Though they work best as a duo, Iâ€™ve recently found a lot to enjoy on 8Ballâ€™s solo debut Lost. A double-album (technically a triple-album if you include the Suave House sampler bonus disc, which is not streaming) largely forgotten in the 90s rap canon, it is remarkably consistent in style and quality, with great guest features and an even better solo performance. In this way it reminds me of E-40â€™s The Element of Surprise, one of my favorite double-albums ever.

40 Water is present here, along with Goodie Mob, Busta Rhymes, and of course MJG. But Ball shines brightest. On single â€œMy Homeboyâ€™s Girlfriendâ€, he spins a tale that is both hilarious and tragic, and sings the hook. His storytelling is in full effect on this track and â€œTimeâ€, a dramatic reminiscence on a friendship gone sour. There are straight-up bangers too, like the MJG-featuring â€œLetâ€™s Rideâ€ and the penultimate â€œGett Buckedâ€ (classic Memphis phrase right there). My favorite guest spot comes from Redman, who in the late 90s was just scorching every feature (see also: The Luniz â€œHypnotizeâ€).

This is one of those albums that is so long you really canâ€™t mention every track. The production is all in-house and somewhat dated, and there is some filler here and there. But itâ€™s worth a look, especially if youâ€™ve checked out 8Ball and MJGâ€™s high-water mark On Top of the World and want more.

Listen to Lost here.

Iâ€™d like to dedicate this post to De La Soulâ€™s Dave, AKA Trugoy, who passed away recently. On 2Pacâ€™s 1995 track â€œOld Schoolâ€, Pac reminisces on the incomparable times and artists who shaped him, and De La are namedropped in the first verse. I think that begins to illustrate how important and influential De La are, and Dave was a core part of that.

Rewind to 1991: Despite the goofy title, 2Pacalypse Now is a remarkably mature and political debut album from a 19-turning-on-20 year old soon-to-be-superstar, one that laid the groundwork for music like Kendrickâ€™s To Pimp a Butterfly.

As exemplified in Kendrickâ€™s â€œMortal Manâ€, 2Pac was incredibly prescient. His first single, â€œTrappedâ€, is a 5-minute story of racial profiling. Although it lacks some of the more profoundly emotional delivery of his later work, â€œTrappedâ€ is a strong and unified lyrical display. It serves as not only a strong start to Pacâ€™s rap career but a signpost of what may be his most overtly political full-length. You can hear the roots of Kendrickâ€™s style on â€œWords of Wisdomâ€: itâ€™s a jazzy interlude which finds Pac rewriting the etymology of the n-word and fast-paced rapping about Americaâ€™s racial suppression.

During these nascent stages of Pacâ€™s rap career, he was in the Bay area recording this album in Richmond. As he would go on to rap on the title track of his second album, Strictly 4 My N.I.G.G.A.Z., â€œIâ€™m cominâ€™ out of O-Town, bitch, fuck aroundâ€. That album would find Tupac at his most aggressive, whereas 2Pacalypse is more relaxed in production and delivery. â€œSouljaâ€™s Storyâ€ employs the same smoky Isaac Hayes sample (â€œNo Name Barâ€) as Tommy Wright and DJ Paul would (separately) employ later for some defining Memphis atmosphere.

â€œI Donâ€™t Give a Fuckâ€ finds Pac with couplets that set 2Pacalypse firmly in the early 90s, rapâ€™s Golden Age: â€œAnd now they tryna send me to Kuwait? / Give me a breakâ€¦ Whoâ€™s that behind the trigger? / A motherfuckinâ€™ 90s ni**a.â€ Itâ€™s a blueprint for the young Shakur, one that he would re-shape and transcend until his death.

â€œBrendaâ€™s Got a Babyâ€ is probably the most popular song from 2Pacalypse, but in its intensely melodramatic presentation is also one of the most dated. Still, itâ€™s a classic storytelling rap in the conscious style. This one and the Stevie Wonder quoting â€œPart Time Muthaâ€, with its strange placement as an album closer, are probably the only 2 tracks here I would skip.

For the amount of music he recorded and the impact he has on pop culture, itâ€™s still mind-boggling how short 2Pacâ€™s career was. Killed in 1996 less than 3 months after his 25th birthday, Pac had spent nearly all of 1995 in prison, a superstar missing in action. Listening to 2Pacalypse today is like watching a fuse get lit. Itâ€™s a reminder that even in the beginning, 2Pac was something special.

Listen to 2Pacalypse Now here.

I didnâ€™t know much about Black Rob before he passed in 2021, except his song â€œCan I Liveâ€ with The LOX, which has a beautiful beat and finds Styles P fantasizing about â€œhang-glid[ing] to the Alps with a fly chickâ€. One of Bad Boyâ€™s most promising artists after Biggieâ€™s passing, Rob was featured on Motownâ€™s â€œI Want You Back â€™98â€, a Jackson 5 remix that dropped, strangely, not 30 but 29 years after the original. Why this track was made, Iâ€™m not sure, but rapping on a track with (the then-living) Michael Jackson must have been a promising early-career move for Rob.

What followed in 1999 was the recording of Robâ€™s debut Life Story, including the smash lead single â€œWhoa!â€, which has largely held up well (other than the f-slur). The Buckwild beat is bonkers, and Black Rob sells the single title as a catchall response to anything remarkable. Also worth pointing out is the 8-minute remix with Rah Digga, Beanie Sigel and more. Whoa.

But Life Story is a surprisingly solid front-to-back album. The title track is captivating as a wistful growing-up-in-the-ghetto song (â€œliving in this tenement, eating stale Entenmannâ€™sâ€). Robâ€™s character is quickly established: a hard-nosed jailbird who perseveres through life struggles by rapping. Somewhat unexpectedly, CeeLo Green appears as the albumâ€™s first rap feature on â€œLookinâ€™ at Usâ€, and he kills it. Sometimes I forgot how good at rapping CeeLo is. Then we have a Bad Boy posse cut with Diddy, Mase and G-Dep on â€œDown the Line Jointâ€.

Later on, â€œB.R.â€ is some expert noir-rap with gritty rhymes and the beat to match. â€œThug Storyâ€ is a Slick Rick callback, and â€œJasmineâ€ is steel-drum infected storytelling rap. â€œI Love You Babyâ€ originally appeared on the Puff & The Family album No Way Out (1997), which went 7x Platinum. Things wrap up with some pep on â€œI Dare Youâ€ (thatâ€™s after the J-Lo feature). I really like this album. Itâ€™s packed to the gills but there is nary a garbage track to be found. God bless Black Rob.

Listen to Life Story here.

This release from two LA-to-the-core hip-hop artists is an overlooked joint project. Itâ€™s a merging of two different generations: The 31-year-old Domo Genesis cut his teeth as a member of Tumblr-era phenoms Odd Future, and the 46-year-old Evidence co-founded the group Dilated Peoples in the 90s. What the two have in common is a laidback, uncomplicated approach to rap music. While this trait may have kept both artists from achieving the mainstream success achieved by some of their peers, it rewards listeners as they age with confidence and consistency in their respective outputs.

Evidence and Domo first collaborated on 2017â€™s â€œDeez Nutsâ€, a Domo track produced by Evidence. A year later, Ev rapped on Domoâ€™s â€œFuck a Co-Signâ€, from his brief yet excellent Arent U Glad Youre U tape. Evidence produced the entirety of last yearâ€™s Intros, Outros and Interludes, and his beats are absolutely lush. I find myself playing this album early in the morning as it relaxes me. â€œTrust the Processâ€ finds Doms riding over a 70s soul sample, his lyrics unadorned observation: â€œThis hash is in my lungs / a bunch of plastic in the oceanâ€. The sunny â€œStay One More Dayâ€ sample fades in and out as Evidence proves himself a master beatmaker.

Evâ€™s one guest verse is smooth: â€œDrive slow, homie / Like my son is in the car / My summers as a kid in Brooklyn made me to a starâ€. This is a reference to canon hip-hop (Late Registration), a sly nod to his age, and a reflection on his come-up in one rhyme. Domo follows with â€œI never had a chance / I lose my life to seek a new one, look we movinâ€™ through the danceâ€. Itâ€™s just two guys ruminating on how they got where they are, but in the context of the album it feels almost like a passing of the torch moment.

The beat on â€œDecember Comingâ€ is heavenly, another delicious piece of a brief yet worthy album from two rap devotees. Hereâ€™s hoping they team up again.

Listen to Introsâ€¦ here.

Itâ€™s been a little while since Jeremih dropped a project. Despite some smash hits throughout the last 13 years or so, his last album was Late Nights in 2015. While that album was critically and commercially successful, I feel that its mixtape follow-up Late Nights: Europe is under-appreciated. Recorded largely on the road during a European tour, Late Nights: Europe feels like an off-the-cuff project that shows just how fire Jeremih was coming off the success of Late Nights.

Talking to Billboard in 2016, Jeremih said â€œin Europeâ€¦ I brought my homie Soundz out with me. I was trying out new treatments while performing. After a lot of the shows, weâ€™d set up small little booths in the hotel room, which I had never done before. Over the last week and a half or two weeks, we came up with a body of work, like 20 songs.â€

â€œAmsterdamâ€ was always my favorite song here. Itâ€™s one of 10 songs here produced by Soundz, who made Rae Sremmurdâ€™s â€œThrow Sum Moâ€ (amongst other things), and the bass-heavy track provides ample room for Jeremih to breathe. Itâ€™s also a track that sticks closely to the theme, with references to the red light district and smoking weed (sounds like Jeremih had a good time in Amsterdam).

Setlist.fm indicates that Jeremih played a show in Beirut on July 9, 2016. Whether or not he played â€œLebanonâ€ there, it sounds like he had a good-ass time there too, as itâ€™s one of the most fun and explicit tracks on the tape. â€œBelgiumâ€ features Chicagoâ€™s trademark juke production. â€œParisâ€ is a collaboration with Ty Dolla $ign, who appeared on the Late Nights album and would eventually make a full-length project with Jeremih (2018â€™s excellent MihTy). I really like that a song called â€œOslo, Norway (feat. The Game)â€ by Jeremih even exists (and itâ€™s good, too!) Things round out back in Jeremihâ€™s hometown with â€œThe Cribâ€, a tribute to Chicago, appropriately featuring G Herbo.

Some of my favorite YouTube comments on the Late Nights: Europe songs:

â€œI be listening to this while travelling Europe wit the love of my lifeâ€ (â€œCzech Republicâ€)

â€œThis tune is real UK undergroundâ€¦ dance doneâ€¦ real road undergroundâ€¦ dance hall business. it was prevalent in the 90â€™s Loose Ends, Cool Notes, Janet Kay, Matumbii etc there is a lot to name so I am most certainly not excluding the great artists of that period of UK Lovers Rock, so itâ€™s nice to see that itâ€™s reformatted for the 2000â€™s similar to what Vybes Kartel has done with Dance Hall basheeeâ€¦. and Popcaan. The tune is tappa tappa.â€ (â€œLondonâ€)

â€œAyyyeâ€ (â€œAmsterdamâ€)

â€œI know my ex playing this with some one else ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚â€ (â€œBritish Headboardsâ€)

Listen to Late Nights: Europe here.

Can I call this the last great Future project? Iâ€™m not mad at him for making 22-track albums that rehash the same territory heâ€™s been in for years â€“ his output from Pluto (2012) to 56 Nights (2015) is still unfuckwithable, and heâ€™s earned the fandom that allows him to operate on cruise control.

But Beastmode 2 stands out among the mixed bag of Future projects over the last 5 years. Like the first Beast Mode (2015), Zaytoven â€“ truly the Beethoven of trap-rap production â€“ handles all the beats here, and the chemistry is palpable. Beastmode 2 is lean at 9 tracks, and holds up well in the era of bloated Deluxe editions.

I appreciate that Future, who had scored a massive hit in 2017 with â€œMask Offâ€, included his OG Young Scooter as the only guest on this tape. â€œDoh Dohâ€ bangs, and it helps Beastmode 2 feel more like a classic early 2010s ATL tape than post-peak Future.

Introspective Future is good Future: see â€œWhen I Think About Itâ€ (â€œIâ€™m droppinâ€™ outta school but that didnâ€™t stop my educationâ€). This is the first of three superb songs that close out the project. â€œSome Moreâ€ finds Fewtch gliding over an icy, beautiful beat. And â€œHate the Real Meâ€ finds Future at his most compelling. Like â€œCodeine Crazyâ€ and â€œThrow Awayâ€ he is reckless, remorseful, self-sabotaging, all over the most thrilling production on the project. Itâ€™s a peak that puts a bow on an outstanding tape with a lot of replay value. As Future himself puts it â€“ the music specialâ€¦ itâ€™s a part of us.

Listen to Beastmode 2 here.

It can be easy to get stuck on Slum Villageâ€™s label debut Fantastic, Vol. 2 (2000), one of the finest hip-hop albums of any era. With J Dilla at the helm, it bumps and grooves on a level that is strictly more beautiful than other records. Itâ€™s not hard to see why Dilla has attained a legendary status, but his absence from Fantastic follow-ups (he left the group to focus on a solo career several years before his death in 2006) leaves them relatively underrated.

Trinity is a great example of this. Take it on its own terms and itâ€™s a very rewarding project. Despite a lack of Dillaâ€™s production (only 3 tracks out of 23), the sound of Slum Village very much remains, in no small part due to the presence of founding member T3 on the boards as well as Detroit producers of the same ilk like Waajeed and Black Milk. Baatinâ€™s trademark voice (similar to Q-Tipâ€™s) carries along from the first album, and a young Elzhi (!) joins as a welcome addition to the crew.

â€œTaintedâ€, produced by Roots-affiliate Karriem Riggins and featuring Dwele, is an early highlight with one of the few classic SV videos. Elzhi sounds energized all over the project, with his verse on â€œLa Laâ€ standing out as a particular scorcher. â€œOneâ€ has one of the wackiest Dilla beats I know of, with a twinkly piano sample and a punching drum. â€œSlumberâ€ bangs with a beat courtesy of Hi-Tek.

At nearly 70 minutes, Trinity could have done with some trimming. I mean, there are 2 intros on this thing. Still, for fans of Fantastic and hip-hop in general, Trinity has a lot to give.

Listen to Trinity here.
